meanings.definition: To remove the flesh or skin from (a corpse or carcass)
meanings.sent1: The forensic scientist was skeletonising the remains to study the bones.
meanings.sent2: The butcher was skeletonising the chicken before cooking it.
meanings.sent3: The Halloween prankster joked about skeletonising the fake skeleton even more.
meanings.sent4: The artist's brush strokes seemed to skeletonise the subject on the canvas.
meanings.sent5: The archaeologist's careful work skeletonised the ancient skeleton for preservation.

meanings.definition: To strip (a building or area) of its internal structures or contents
meanings.sent1: The demolition crew was skeletonising the old building to make space for a new one.
meanings.sent2: The burglars were caught skeletonising the abandoned house for valuable items.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous kids joked about skeletonising their clubhouse for a secret hideout.
meanings.sent4: The storm's strong winds seemed to skeletonise the trees, leaving them bare.
meanings.sent5: The renovation team was skeletonising the office space to create an open floor plan.

meanings.definition: To reduce (something) to its bare essentials or most basic form
meanings.sent1: The editor was skeletonising the lengthy manuscript to meet the word count limit.
meanings.sent2: The teacher was skeletonising the complex topic to explain it to the students.
meanings.sent3: The chef joked about skeletonising the recipe to just salt and pepper.
meanings.sent4: The designer's minimalist approach seemed to skeletonise the fashion collection.
meanings.sent5: The speaker's powerful words skeletonised the complicated issue for everyone to understand.
